Introduction

Endophthalmitis is a severe intraocular infection involving the aqueous and vitreous humors (

figure 1
).  Most cases are caused by bacteria, but fungal infections can occur.  Common presenting symptoms include decreased visual acuity and aching discomfort in the affected eye.  Conjunctival injection, hypopyon (layering of white blood cells in the anterior chamber), and vitreous opacification are characteristic examination findings.  Patients require emergent ophthalmology consultation for administration of intravitreal antimicrobials to prevent permanent vision loss.

Pathophysiology and risk factors



Endophthalmitis is categorized as either exogenous or endogenous infection based on how microorganisms gain access to the intraocular space.



  • Exogenous endophthalmitis occurs when a traumatic disruption of the globe's integrity allows entry of microbes (usually bacteria).  Risk factors include:

    • Ocular surgery (especially cataract surgery)
    • Eye trauma
    • Intravitreal injections
    • Keratitis (corneal infection)
  • Endogenous endophthalmitis occurs when infection spreads hematogenously from another site within the body (eg, bacteremia, fungemia).  Risk factors include:
    • Indwelling central venous catheter
    • Intravenous drug use
    • Gastrointestinal surgery
    • Severe immunocompromise

Bacterial endophthalmitis



Bacterial endophthalmitis is significantly more common than fungal endophthalmitis and most cases are due to exogenous spread (

).  Surgery or trauma can cause contamination of the aqueous humor by conjunctival flora; if inadvertent communication with the vitreous occurs, the bacteria can seed the vitreous, which is much more susceptible to infection.  Coagulase-negative staphylococci (eg, Staphylococcus epidermidis), which colonize the conjunctiva, are the most prevalent pathogens.  Other causative bacteria include S aureus and streptococci species.

Fungal endophthalmitis



Fungal endophthalmitis is rare and most often caused by endogenous spread of Candida to the highly vascular choroid layer of the eye (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
).  The organism replicates in the choroid and attacks the retina, then spreads into the vitreous and aqueous fluids.  Hospitalized patients with indwelling venous catheters and immunosuppression are at highest risk.

Clinical presentation

Bacterial endophthalmitis



Bacterial endophthalmitis typically presents several days after surgery (eg, cataract surgery) or trauma and commonly includes:



  • Decreased vision in the affected eye
  • Aching eye pain
  • Conjunctival injection and edema
  • Hypopyon (layering of white blood cells in the anterior chamber) (
    image 1
    )
  • Vitreous opacification/haziness (due to infiltration of inflammatory cells) making it difficult to visualize the retina

Fungal endophthalmitis



Fungal endophalmitis presents similarly to bacterial endophthalmitis, with the following differences:



  • Symptom onset that is typically slower (days to weeks after fungemia)
  • Eye pain that usually does not occur until late in the disease course
  • Slit-lamp examination that reveals characteristic fluffy, yellow-white chorioretinal lesions

Diagnosis



The diagnosis of endophthalmitis is suspected based on history (eg, decreased vision after recent eye surgery) and abnormal ophthalmologic examination findings (eg, decreased visual acuity, hypopyon, hazy vitreous).



To confirm the diagnosis, a needle aspiration is performed to obtain aqueous and/or vitreous humor samples for microbial culture and sensitivity testing.

Differential diagnosis



  • Acute anterior uveitis: is characterized by inflammation of the iris and anterior chamber.  Clinical features include unilateral eye pain, redness, blurred vision and hypopyon; however, there is no significant vitreous inflammation or haziness on examination.
  • Acute angle-closure glaucoma: involves a sudden increase in intraocular pressure due to obstruction of aqueous humor outflow.  Patients have rapid onset of severe eye pain and blurred vision.  There is often associated vomiting, headache, corneal edema, and a fixed mid-dilated pupil.  Hypopyon and vitreous opacification are not expected.
  • Corneal ulcer: is a defect in the corneal epithelium typically caused by infection (eg, keratitis).  Symptoms include eye pain, redness, foreign body sensation, and photophobia.  Hypopyon may be present on slit-lamp examination, but fluorescein stain reveals a defined corneal abnormality.

Laboratory evaluation



Endophthalmitis is often detected and empirically treated based on clinical findings, but the diagnosis is confirmed by a positive aqueous or vitreous fluid culture.  Positive cultures provide important information about causative organisms and how to guide treatment.  However, a negative culture does not definitively rule out endophthalmitis; if infection is suspected, the patient should continue treatment under the guidance of an ophthalmologist.



Blood cultures are also necessary in cases of presumed endogenous infection because these patients also require systemic antimicrobials to treat the source of infection.

Management



Endophthalmitis is a vision-threatening ocular emergency; management typically involves prompt initiation of the following:



  • Intravitreal antibiotics or antifungals:  Direct injection into the vitreous humor creates effectively high concentrations in the cavity.
  • Adjuvant systemic antibiotics or antifungals:  These are used for suspected or confirmed endogenous infection.
    • Candida endophthalmitis is almost always related to fungemia, so all cases require systemic antifungal treatment.
  • Vitrectomy (surgical removal of the vitreous):  This procedure may be necessary in severe cases with significant vision loss or rapidly advancing vitreal inflammation.

Prognosis



The prognosis of endophthalmitis depends on various factors:



  • Timing of diagnosis:  Early diagnosis and treatment improve visual outcomes, whereas delayed treatment may result in irreversible vision loss.
  • Virulence of the causative microorganism:  Streptococcus and Candida tend to have a poorer prognosis for preserved vision, whereas patients with coagulase-negative staphylococci typically have favorable outcomes.
  • Nature of the infection:  Endogenous bacterial and fungal endophthalmitis are associated with increased risk for permanent vision impairment.


In addition to vision loss, extension of endophthalmitis infection can lead to panophthalmitis (involving all structures of the globe, including the sclera and conjunctiva), which often requires enucleation.

Summary



Endophthalmitis is a vision-threatening ocular emergency due to infection of the inner structures of the eye.  Most cases result from exogenous entry of bacteria after surgery or trauma, but fungal infections may occur in immunocompromised patients.  Clinical findings include vision loss, eye discomfort, hypopyon, and opacification of the vitreous humor.  Endophthalmitis is an ophthalmologic emergency that requires immediate treatment with intravitreal antibiotics to prevent irreversible vision loss.
